title: How to Exercise with a Broken Leg

steps.title: Try seated air punches.
steps.content: Try seated air punches. Sit in a chair with your feet flat on the floor and your back straight. Pretend like there’s a punching bag right in front of you and start punching, alternating your right and left hand. [1] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source Try to do about 25 reps, or as many punches as you can before you get tired. The goal of a cardio exercise is to get your heartrate up. Keep your movements fluid and quick to quicken your breathing and start to sweat.

steps.title: Do some knee taps.
steps.content: Do some knee taps. Sit in a chair with your feet on the floor and your back straight. Lift your left leg off the ground, keeping your knee bent at a 90-degree angle to the floor. Tap your knee with your right hand as it’s in the air. Then, switch legs. [2] X Research source Try doing this exercise for about 5 minutes, or until your heart rate has increased. If you’re wearing a full leg cast (meaning you can’t bend your knee), just do knee taps on your non-broken leg.

steps.title: Try arm swings.
steps.content: Try arm swings. Sit in a chair with your posture upright and your feet flat. Keeping your elbows bent, swing your arms back and forth, like you’re running in place. [3] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source Do this for about 5 minutes, or until you get tired. You can swing your arms both in the same direction, or do alternate directions.

steps.title: Do chest presses with a resistance band.
steps.content: Do chest presses with a resistance band . Sit in a chair and wrap a resistance band underneath the seat of the chair. Hold either end of the band in each hand, with your palms facing forward. Press the band away from yourself, keeping your hands held at chest height. Do this for 25 to 30 reps, or until you start feeling tired. [4] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source Make sure the resistance band is fully secured beneath your chair. If it slips out from underneath the chair, it could hit your body. Choose a resistance band that’s right for your strength level. Most beginners start out with the lowest resistance band.

steps.title: Try a standing leg lift to target your obliques.
steps.content: Try a standing leg lift to target your obliques. Stand next to a chair with your good leg (the non-broken one) closest to the chair. Hold the chair with one hand for stability, and slowly raise your broken leg out to the side until it’s about 6 inches (15 cm) off the floor. Lower your leg back down, then repeat this 7 to 9 times. [5] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source As you raise and lower your legs, engage your core by squeezing your abs and your obliques.

steps.title: Try some crunches to engage your lower abs.
steps.content: Try some crunches to engage your lower abs. Lie flat on the floor with your legs bent and knees pointing toward the ceiling. If your leg is in a full cast, keep your leg straight instead of bending it. Put your hands behind your head to support your neck, and engage your abs to lift your shoulders off the ground. [6] X Trustworthy Source American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists Professional association of OB/GYNs focused on education and public outreat initiatives Go to source Do crunches 10 to 20 times, or until your abs are fatigued.

steps.title: Do a segmental rotation to target your upper abs.
steps.content: Do a segmental rotation to target your upper abs. Lie flat on the ground with your legs bent and your knees pointing up. If you are in a full leg cast, keep your leg straight instead of bending it. Engage your abs and let your knees fall to 1 side, going as far as you can while keeping your back flat on the ground. Hold the position for 3 deep breaths, then repeat on the other side. [7] X Research source Try doing this exercise 5 to 10 times, or until your ab muscles are fatigued.

steps.title: Engage your biceps with a seated bicep curl.
steps.content: Engage your biceps with a seated bicep curl. Sit in a chair with your legs in a comfortable position and your feet flat on the ground. Grab a dumbbell in 1 hand and curl it up toward your shoulder, engaging your bicep the entire time. Slowly lower the dumbbell back down to repeat 1 repetition. [8] X Research source Try doing 8 to 10 repetitions to start before moving onto your other arm. Most arm dumbbell exercises can be converted into a seated position. If you have a favorite arm exercise you’d like to try, see if you can do it while sitting down!

steps.title: Try a seated overhead press to work your shoulders.
steps.content: Try a seated overhead press to work your shoulders. Grab a dumbbell in each hand and lift them up to about shoulder height. Slowly lift your arms upward, keeping your palms facing forward, until your arms are straight. Lower the dumbbells back down to chest-height for 1 rep. [9] X Research source Try doing 15 repetitions to start. The weight of your dumbbells is up to you. If you’re a beginner, go for 5 pounds (2.3 kg) or 10 pounds (4.5 kg) to start.

steps.title: Do a seated tricep extension to target the back of your arms.
steps.content: Do a seated tricep extension to target the back of your arms. While seated, hold a dumbbell in each hand with your palms facing behind you. Lift your weights straight up, bending your elbows at a 90-degree angle. Keeping your elbows in the same position, slowly straighten your arms and engage your triceps. Then, slowly return to your starting position to work your triceps . [10] X Research source Do this exercise 15 times to start out with, and add more as you get stronger.

steps.title: Work your arms, shoulders, and back with a seated upright row.
steps.content: Work your arms, shoulders, and back with a seated upright row. While sitting in a chair, hold a dumbbell in each hand with your palms facing your legs. Slowly lift the dumbbells to shoulder-level, letting your elbows point outward. Engage your back to hold the position for a few seconds, then lower back down to do 1 rep of a dumbbell row. [11] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Try to do at least 15 repetitions. If you feel up to it, you can rest and then go for 15 more reps.

steps.title: Strengthen your thigh with leg lifts.
steps.content: Strengthen your thigh with leg lifts. Lie flat with your good leg bent and your broken leg straight out. Raise your broken leg 1 to 2 in (2.5 to 5.1 cm) off the ground, then hold it for 2 to 3 seconds. Slowly lower your leg back down, then repeat this up to 10 times. [12] X Research source Strengthening the muscles around your broken leg may be able to help it heal faster. You can do this exercise up to 4 times per day.

steps.title: Engage your quads with a knee bend.
steps.content: Engage your quads with a knee bend. Sit in a chair with your feet flat on the ground and your back straight. Straighten 1 leg out and lift it off the ground as high as you can, then hold it for 5 seconds. Repeat this exercise 10 times on each leg. [13] X Research source This is a great alternative to squats you can do while your leg heals.

steps.title: Keep your ankles strong with ankle rotations.
steps.content: Keep your ankles strong with ankle rotations. Since you aren’t walking on your leg for a few weeks (or months), it’s important to keep your ankles in good shape. Sit in a chair with your feet in a comfortable position and slowly move your ankle up and down. Try to do this at least 10 times. If your broken bone is near your ankle, ask your doctor about this exercise before you do it.
